origin.value: %w means "mysterious", and %w means "seed." It translates to "mysterious seed". It can also mean %w, "Isn’t it strange?".
%w means "mysterious" and %w means "grass." It translates to "mysterious grass".
%w means "mysterious" and %w means "flower". It translates to "mysterious flower".
%w means "fire" and %w means "lizard". It translates to "fire lizard".
From the English word "lizard", written in katakana as リザード.
A combination of "lizard" (リザード) and the suffix "don" (ドン), often used for large or strong creatures.
A %w is a young Japanese pond turtle. It's round shell ressembles a %w edo period coin.
A combination of %w which means turtle and either "mail" in English or "mer" in French.
A combination of %w which means turtle and either "X" in Japanese, "max" in English or "rex" in Latin.
From the English word "caterpillar", written in katakana as キャタピラー.
A combination of the English words "transformation" (トランスフォーメーション) and either "shell" (シェル) or "cell" (セル).
A combination of the English words "butterfly" (バタフライ) and "free" (フリー).
A combination of the English words "bee" (ビー) and "needle" (ニードル).
From the English word "cocoon" (コクーン).
From the English word "spear" (スピア). It is also an anagram of "apis" (アピス), the genus of the honey bee.
Onomatopoeia for the cry of a pigeon in Japanese.
From the English word "pigeon" (ピジョン).
A combination of the English words "pigeon" (ピジョン) and either "parrot" (パロット) or "jet" (ジェット).
From it's evolution ラッタ. In Japanese baby animals are prefixed with コ (小) which would translates to "baby ラッタ" here.
From the English word "rat" (ラット).
%w means "demon" and %w means "sparrow". It translates to "demon sparrow".
%w means "demon" and ドリル is the English word "drill".
From the English word "boa" (ボア).
From the English word "cobra" (コブラ).
From either the "pika" rabbit in English or %w the Japanese onomatopoeia for something sparkly and %w the Japanese onomatopoeia for the squeak of mice.
%w means "thunder" and %w is the Japanese onomatopoeia for the squeak of mice.
From the English word "sand" (サンド).
From the English words "sand" (サンド) and "pangolin" (パンゴリン).
From the English words "needle" (ニードル).
From the English word "needle" (ニードル) and the italian feminine modifier "-a".
From the English words "needle" (ニードル) and "queen" (クイーン).
From the English words "needle" (ニードル).
From the English word "needle" (ニードル) and the italian masculine modifier "-o".
From the English words "needle" (ニードル) and "king" (キング).
From the English words "pixie" (ピクシ) and from "pippi" (ぴっぴっ) the Japanese onomatopoeia for a shaking finger.
From the English words "pixie" (ピクシ).
From %w which means six and %w which is the Japanese onomatopoeia for the cry of foxes.
From %w which means nine and %w which is the Japanese onomatopoeia for the cry of foxes. It is also a reference to the nine-tailed fox from Chinese mythology.
From the English word "pretty" (プリティ) and from %w which means pudding in Japanese and is a type of dessert.
From the English word "pretty" (プリティ) and from %w which means to swell.
From the English word "bat" (バット)、from the word %w which means "straight away" and could also be a reference to %w a superhero TV series that aired in 1977.
From the English words "ghoul" (グルー) and "bat" (バット), could also be a reference to %w a showa era picture-story superhero.
From %w meaning "mysterious" and %w meaning "grass", litterally "mysterious grass".
From %w meaning "smelly" and %w meaning "flower", litterally "smelly flower".
From the rafflesia (ラフレシア) flower.
From "parasite" (パラザイト) and/or "parasol" (パラソル).
From "parasite" (パラザイト) and "insect" (インセクト).
From "compound eye" (コンパン　アイ).
From %w, the morfo butterflies genus.
From "dig" (ディグ) and the %w Namco video game.
From "dug" (ダグ), the %w Namco video game and "trio" (トリオ).
From Pokemon game creator Satoshi Tajiri's pet cat name, and from %w onomatopoeia for cat meow.
From "persian" (ペルシアン) and "russian blue" (ロシアンブルー) cat breeds.
From "duck" (ダック) and %w meaning "small" or "baby".
From "gold" (ゴルド) and "duck" (ダック).
From "monkey" (モンキ) and "mandrill" (マンドリル).
From %w meaning "anger" and %w meaning "monkey".
From "guard" (ガ−ド).
From "wind" (ウインド) and "windy" (ウインディ).
From %w, an onomatopoeia for something that slithers, wriggles, or moves in a twisting, snake-like manner.
From %w, an onomatopoeia for something that slithers, wriggles, or moves in a twisting, snake-like manner.
From %w, an onomatopoeia for something that slithers, %w used to refer to a young boy and %w meaning "compressed gas cylinder".
From "Cayce" (ケイシー), referring to Edgar Cayce an american clairvoyant.
From "Uri Geller" (ユリ ゲラー), an Israeli-British illusionist, magician, television personality, and self-proclaimed psychic.
From "Houdini" (フーディーニ), referring to Harry Houdini a Hungarian-American escape artist, illusionist, and stunt performer noted for his escape acts.
From %w, meaning arm strength.
From %w or %w, both meaning strong / strength.
From %w, meaning superhuman strength.
From %w, meaning "still" and %w, meaning "flower bud". Literally "still a flower bud".
From %w, meaning "nepenthes rafflesiana" a species of tropical pitcher plant.
From %w, meaning "nepenthes rafflesiana" a species of tropical pitcher plant, and "pot" (ポット) or "pod" (ポッド).
From %w, meaning "jellyfish", and %w, meaning "agate".
From %w, meaning "poison", and %w, meaning "jellyfish".
From %w, meaning "stone", and %w, meaning "pebble".
From %w, the onomatopoeia of something rolling, and "stone" (ストーン).
From %w, the onomatopoeia of something rolling, "stone" (ストーン) and "montagna" (モンタニャ).
From "pony" (ポーニ) and "señorita" (セニョリータ).
From "gallop" (ガロップ).
From %w, meaning "hermit crab", and %w, meaning "thickheaded".
From %w, meaning "hermit crab", and %w, transliterated first name of "Jadranka Stojaković" a Yugoslavian singer acquainted with members of the Pokémon development team.
From "coil" (コイル).
From "rare metal" (レアメタル) and "coil" (コイル).
From %w, meaning "wild duck", and %w, meaning "welsh onion". Slang expression for a stroke of good luck.
From "dodo" (ドードー), an extinct bird endemic to the island of Mauritius.
From "dodo" (ドードー), an extinct bird endemic to the island of Mauritius, and "trio" (トリオ).
From %w, the onomatopoeia for the cry of a sea lion.
From %w, meaning "dugong".
From %w and %w, both meaning "sticky".
From %w, meaning "sticky", and %w, suffix for large or strong creatures.
From "shell" (シェル) and "shelter" (シェルタ).
From "pearl shell" (ペルシェル).
From "ghost" (ゴースト) and "gas" (ガス). Reference to the "Ultraseven" tv show which features monsters called %w.
From "ghost" (ゴースト).
From "doppelgänger" (ドッペルゲンガー).
From %w, meaning "boulder", and "snake" (スネーク).
From "sleep" (スリープ).
From "sleeper" (スリーパー), and "tapir" (テイパー).
From "crab" (クラブ).
From "king" (キング), "king krab" (キングクラブ). Reference to the "Ultraman A" tv series which features a monster called %w.
From %w, an onomatopoeia for eletric current, and %w, meaning "ball".
Anagram of %w, meaning "perfectly round". From %w, meaning "round" and "mine" (マイン).
From %w, meaning "ball", and/or %w, meaning "egg".
From %w, meaning "nuts", and/or %w, meaning "palm", and/or %w, meaning "date palm".
From %w, an onomatopoeia for a clattering or rattling noise.
From %w, an onomatopoeia for a clattering or rattling noise.
